title: Day in the Life of an IL Dairy Farmer #shorts

subtasks: Rising early in the morning (4 a.m.)
Heading to the barn to tend to cows
Transferring milk to the bulk tank for cooling
Spending extra time with a specific calf (Gloria's red baby)
Repeating milking process in the evening (around 4 p.m.)
Caring for a newborn calf (Gloria's red baby)
Providing special attention to the calf
Rising early in the morning (4 a.m.)
Heading to the barn to meet cows
Transferring milk to the bulk tank
Spending extra time with Gloria's red baby calf
Heading to the barn and milking cows (positioning, cleaning teats, attaching machines, monitoring, collecting/moving milk)
Extra care for the red calf

tasks.task: Evening milking operations involving the same tasks (though start after completing existing chores). However, maybe it's considered one maintask (day's operations), with two major activities (morning and evening milkings). But since in reality, a dairy farmer would have two milkings each day, these are distinct times.

the morning with its own set of tasks and evening milking. Therefore, more appropriate to separate those into two MAINTASKs. Given the transcript describes the farmer starting milking again after the morning schedule is done, perhaps a single MAINTASK for daily operations with two steps: morning milk and evening milk. But how?

Dairy farming operations (full day). In which case, the feeding calves would be necessary in both the morning and evening. But since only it mentions spending extra time with a red calf today. Maybe this is a new calf in the late part of the day, leading to extra feeding then.
Daily dairy farming operations (morning to evening)
Dairy farming operations (covering morning and evening), which includes all tasks. However, if the farmer doesn't feed calves in the evening, then the evening section would lack feeding.
